items.title: Stock market recovers some earlier losses while waiting on Nvidia earnings report
items.summary_auto: Wall Street bounced back from this week's earlier losses on Wednesday, ahead of the latest earnings report from Nvidia, considered a bellwether for the artificial intelligence sector.

items.title: For the first time, the woman who Jacob Hoggard was convicted of sexually assaulting is revealing her identity
items.summary_auto: Throughout the sexual assault trial of Hedley frontman Jacob Hoggard, the woman was referred to by her initials, J.B., or as the “Ottawa woman.” Now, she’s lifting the publication ban on her identity as she tells her own story in the documentary Breaking Idol.

items.title: Several arrests made in connection with railway blast, Polish state media says
items.summary_auto: Polish authorities have arrested several people in connection with a blast that damaged a rail line linking Warsaw to the Ukrainian border over the weekend, state media reported Wednesday.

items.title: Israel warns 2 villages in southern Lebanon to evacuate ahead of strikes
items.summary_auto: An Israeli airstrike on a car in southern Lebanon on Wednesday killed one person and wounded 11, including students aboard a nearby bus, the Lebanese Health Ministry and state media said. The strike in the village of Tiri came hours after an Israeli drone attack on the Palestinian refugee camp of Ein el-Hilweh killed 13 people and wounded several others.

items.title: Alberta already has sky-high car insurance rates. Will 120 km/h speed limits send premiums higher?
items.summary_auto: Vehicle insurance companies are going to keep a close watch on whether the Alberta government keeps driving forward with a proposal to increase some highway speed limits to 120km/h.

items.title: Online scams on the rise as holidays approach, security experts warn
items.summary_auto: With Black Friday and Cyber Monday fast approaching, security experts are warning people to be careful when buying online.

items.title: Heavy Russian attack on Ukraine kills 19, injures dozens, officials say
items.summary_auto: Nineteen people were killed in a heavy overnight Russian missile and drone attack that struck an apartment building in the western Ukrainian city of Ternopil, Ukrainian officials said on Wednesday.

items.title: Looming military radar project creates deep anxiety for rural Ontario community
items.summary_auto: Family farms in Clearview Township, Ont., face uncertainty after the Department of National Defence proposed a $38-billion NORAD radar project. Generations of farmers fear losing land to the military, raising tension between national security plans and rural heritage.

items.title: 16 going on 60: How well has The Sound of Music aged?
items.summary_auto: This year marks the 60th anniversary of the film adaptation of The Sound of Music. Decades on, fans and critics alike are revisiting the film and reconsidering its legacy as well as what it has to say about the world today.

items.title: Carney heads to U.A.E. hoping to sign investment pact with gulf nation
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney is slated to meet with United Arab Emirates President Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan in Abu Dhabi with the explicit focus on expanding the Canada-U.A.E. economic partnership in key sectors such as energy, agriculture, infrastructure and AI.

items.title: The people who inspire CBC Massey Lecturer Alex Neve to fight for human rights
items.summary_auto: When he was eight, 2025 CBC Massey Lecturer Alex Neve watched his mother fight for daycare in Alberta. It’s shaped how he thinks about human rights. The Canadian lawyer shares the pivotal moments in his life that led to his human rights advocacy — and shines a light on the chorus of people he carries with him.

items.title: 1 of 25 students abducted in Nigeria found safe as search continues for missing girls
items.summary_auto: A schoolgirl who was abducted with 24 others from a dormitory in northwestern Nigeria has escaped and is safe, the school's principal told The Associated Press on Tuesday, as hunters joined security forces in the search for the missing students in forests close to the school.

items.title: Once shunned,  Saudi crown prince is Trump’s guest of honour. Canada is warming up, too
Danielle Smith's notwithstanding clause triple play on trans youth rights
U.S.-bound cargo barge takes on water near Bella Bella, B.C.
items.summary_auto: A U.S.-bound cargo ship was damaged and is taking on water near Bella Bella on B.C. 's Central Coast, officials say.

items.title: B.C. redrawing EV sales mandate, scraps goal of 100% by 2035, leaves rebates to feds
items.summary_auto: British Columbia has abandoned a rebate program for electric vehicles that it paused six months ago and is scrapping a mandate that every new vehicle sold in the province must be zero-emission by 2035.

items.title: Bo Bichette declines qualifying offer from Toronto Blue Jays
items.summary_auto: Bo Bichette has declined a qualifying offer from the Toronto Blue Jays, meaning the major-league veteran of seven seasons will opt to choose his next deal from what he is offered on the open market.

items.title: Toronto woman who suffocated 2 sons gets life with no chance of parole for 18 years
items.summary_auto: A Toronto woman who suffocated her sons two years ago has been sentenced to life in prison without a chance of parole for 18 years.

items.title: CRTC updates definition of Canadian content, putting limits on AI use
items.summary_auto: The federal broadcast regulator has released a new definition of Canadian content — and humans, not AI, must maintain creative control in order to qualify.

items.title: Ottawa Charge won't play at smaller Lansdowne arena, PWHL says
items.summary_auto: "We'd like to find a solution that works for us to stay in Ottawa," a league executive says of the Ottawa Charge. "But the city hasn't made it easy for us."

items.title: Have you seen spotted lanternfly eggs in Windsor-Essex? Invasive Species Centre urges vigilance
items.summary_auto: Canada's Invasive Species Centre held a workshop at Windsor's Ojibway Nature Centre to raise local awareness of the spotted lanternfly — and its egg masses. The Asian plant-eating insect is expected to have a major impact on Canada's wine and fruit-farming industries.

items.title: Canada Post paints bleak financial picture, hints at big job cuts
items.summary_auto: At its annual public meeting Tuesday, Canada Post revealed that it continues to bleed cash and hinted at big job cuts through attrition.

items.title: Is the U.S. starving for Canadian travellers? | About That
items.summary_auto: Canadian travel to the United States has dropped sharply since President Donald Trump retook office earlier this year. Andrew Chang breaks down the numbers to explain the impact on the U.S. economy, and how many American businesses are trying to win Canadians back. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

items.title: Facebook owner Meta wins U.S. antitrust case, won't have to break off Instagram, WhatsApp
items.summary_auto: Meta has prevailed over an existential challenge to its business that could have forced the tech giant to spin off Instagram and WhatsApp after a judge ruled that the company does not hold a monopoly in social networking.

items.title: Alleged Ryan Wedding associate from Montreal faces murder charge, extradition to U.S.
items.summary_auto: A man alleged to have ties to organized crime in Montreal is facing charges in relation to a murder and cocaine trafficking, and is now facing extradition to the United States.

items.title: 20 people stuck in elevator at the deepest light-rail station in Canada — on 1st day of service
items.summary_auto: On the first day the new Deux-Montagnes line of Montreal’s light-rail network was officially in full operation, an elevator carrying commuters at Édouard-Montpetit station broke down for an hour.

items.title: Alberta to invoke notwithstanding clause to shield 3 transgender bills from court challenges
items.summary_auto: The Alberta government has tabled legislation that seeks to invoke the notwithstanding clause to shield a suite of bills that affects transgender youth and adults from legal challenges.

items.title: Thousands of bald eagles descend on B.C.’s Fraser Valley for winter migration
items.summary_auto: Every winter, tens of thousands of bald eagles descend on the lower Fraser Valley — a migration biologists say forms the world’s largest congregation of eagles.

items.title: Team Canada unveils athlete outfits for Milan-Cortina Olympics, Paralympics
Gustav Klimt painting sells for $236M US, smashing auction records
items.summary_auto: A Gustav Klimt painting that helped save the life of its Jewish subject during the Holocaust sold Tuesday for $236.4 million US — smashing several records.

items.title: Proposal to ban raising of national flags at Calgary city hall delayed
items.summary_auto: The proposal, brought forward by Ward 13 Coun. Dan McLean, called for council to discuss amendments to Calgary's flag policy during its scheduled public hearing meeting as an "urgent business" matter.

items.title: Manitoba throne speech promises supervised consumption site by January, overpass at site of deadly bus crash
items.summary_auto: Manitoba’s NDP government is promising to build, saying in its third throne speech that it will construct an overpass at the location of a bus crash that killed 17 seniors, set up the province’s first supervised consumption site and build a new fuel-burning generation station to stave off a forecast power shortage.
